titleStmt.title: Can Teaching Calculation and Estimation Strategies Improve Financial Decision-Making? The Role of Emotions and Deliberation

analytic.title: Can Teaching Calculation and Estimation Strategies Improve Financial Decision-Making? The Role of Emotions and Deliberation

biblStruct.note: Note: This is a preprint of a manuscript that has been submitted for publication. Version number: 1

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Financial decision-making often involves numerical reasoning. For example, monetary lotteries-a common task in economic psychology-require evaluating payoffs and probabilities. To make decisions consistent with normative standards like Expected Value (EV), individuals must accurately perform calculations. However, many people lack objective numeracy or numeric selfefficacy, which limits their ability to make EV-consistent choices and maximize earnings. This study tested whether brief interventions could enhance financial decision-making and emotional responses during such tasks. Participants were randomly assigned to one of three conditions: Control, Calculation, or Estimation. In the Control condition, participants made choices in ten monetary lotteries. In the Calculation condition, they received instructions on how to compute EV before the task. In the Estimation condition, they were additionally trained in estimation strategies to simplify calculations. Results indicated marginal effects of the interventions on both EV-consistent choices and negative emotional reactions. Planned comparisons showed that participants in the Calculation condition made significantly more EV-consistent choices than those in the Control condition. Notably, deliberation time-but not emotional reactions-mediated the relationship between condition and EV-consistent choices. Participants in the Calculation condition spent more time deliberating, which contributed to better decision-making. In summary, the findings provide evidence that teaching EV calculation can improve financial decision-making by promoting deliberation. While the interventions had limited effects, they suggest that even brief educational strategies may support more rational economic choices. Materials and data

div.p: In school, experiences with math varied widely-some of us dreaded every class, others felt indifferent, and a few eagerly looked forward to it. Negative experiences might have stemmed from harsh teachers, being told we weren't good enough with numbers or struggles with math anxiety.

While much research focuses on improving math education in childhood and adolescence (e.g., Justicia-Galiano et al., 2017;Vukovic et al., 2013) far less attention has been given to the role of numeracy skills and math anxiety in adulthood (as exceptions; Peters, 2020;Peters et al., 2017;Skagerlund et al., 2018;. This gap is particularly concerning, as adults frequently face complex financial decisions that require numerical competence, yet many struggle due to insufficient skills or lingering anxiety.

div.head: Numeracy and Financial Decision Making
div.p: Objective numeracy-the ability to understand and process basic information about probabilities and numbers-plays a crucial role in shaping decision outcomes in both experimental settings and real-life contexts (e.g., Garcia-Retamero et al., 2019;Peters, 2020;Sobkow, Garrido, et al., 2020). Research has shown that numeracy is a significant predictor of better financial decisionmaking in real-life scenarios, including investment choices, debt management, and overall financial well-being (Peters, 2020;Sobkow, Garrido, et al., 2020). For instance, large-scale studies using U.S. samples (n = 4,572) have demonstrated that higher numeracy correlates with improved financial knowledge and greater financial well-being (Peters et al., 2012). Additionally, Estrada-Mejía et al. (2016) found a correlation between numeracy and wealth accumulation over a five-year period.

Remarkably, numeracy also emerged as a significant predictor of wealth in agrarian communities in Peru (Estrada-Mejia et al., 2020). Furthermore, numeracy has been linked to income, income satisfaction, and overall life satisfaction, even when accounting for factors such as education or intelligence (Bjälkebring & Peters, 2021). These findings underscore the vital role that numeracy plays in facilitating effective financial decision-making across diverse populations and socioeconomic contexts.

Nevertheless, to better understand the psychological mechanisms underlying these effects, researchers often utilize more standardized paradigms, such as monetary lotteries, in their experimental studies. For instance, it has been demonstrated that objective numeracy is a robust predictor of choices aligned with the Expected Value (EV) principle, which involves multiplying potential payoffs by their probabilities in monetary lotteries (e.g., Cokely & Kelley, 2009;Sobkow et al., 2025;Sobkow, Olszewska, et al., 2020). Maximizing expected value helps people make better decisions by weighing potential gains against losses, which is why it's often used as a guide for identifying rational or well-justified choices.

By utilizing paradigms such as monetary lotteries, researchers aim to uncover the mechanisms underlying the tendency of individuals with higher numeracy to make better financial decisions. One perspective is that numeracy serves as a foundation for specialized 'mindware' or 'computation engine' that individuals apply in the financial decision-making process (Skagerlund et al., 2018;Stanovich et al., 2016). Alternatively, the Skilled Decision Theory (Cokely et al., 2018) suggests that individuals with greater objective numeracy excel not simply because they rely on Expected Value calculations but because they develop a more nuanced understanding of the situation and apply heuristics more effectively.

In their study, Cokely and Kelley (2009) examined the psychological processes underlying this effect using verbal protocol analysis. They found that while some participants verbalized Expected Value calculations, most relied on simplified heuristic strategies. More broadly, research suggests that highly numerate individuals engage more in deliberative heuristic search (Ashby, 2017) and allocate more time to decision tasks, ultimately enhancing their performance (Ghazal et al., 2014).

However, other studies highlight boundary conditions for this effect. Traczyk et al. (2018) and Mondal et al. (2025) found that individuals with higher objective numeracy adopted more effortful strategies only when beneficial. Under time constraints, they sampled information more rapidly and dynamically to explore the structure of the environment. These findings suggest that superior decision-making stems not only from performing calculations but also from employing effective estimation strategies.

Nevertheless, better financial outcomes may stem not only from the use of effective strategies but also from motivational and emotional factors that shape decision-making processes. Research suggests that subjective numeracy and math anxiety complement objective numeracy in predicting financial decision outcomes (Peters et al., 2012(Peters et al., , 2017Peters & Shoots-Reinhard, 2022;Sobkow, Olszewska, et al., 2020;.

Numeric self-efficacy, a key component of subjective numeracy, reflects an individual's belief in their ability to successfully engage with numerical tasks. Higher numeric self-efficacy is associated with greater motivation and persistence as well as fewer negative emotional reactions to math (Peters & Bjälkebring, 2015;Peters & Shoots-Reinhard, 2022). In contrast, individuals with low numeric self-efficacy often experience heightened math anxiety, which can function as both a trait and a state, varying between individuals and across situations (Cipora et al., 2022;Maloney & Beilock, 2012;Sammallahti et al., 2023;Sidney et al., 2025). Math anxiety may impair problem-solving through multiple mechanisms. First, it can reduce working memory capacity, limiting cognitive resources available for numerical reasoning. Second, it can diminish motivation, leading individuals to avoid math-related tasks, including financial decisions. We argue that individuals with low numeric self-efficacy or high math anxiety often experience heightened negative emotions when faced with numerical tasks, such as monetary lotteries (Michalik et al., 2024). This emotional distress can lead to lower persistence and increased task avoidance, ultimately impairing financial decision-making.

div.head: Overview of the current research
div.p: Building on these mechanisms, the current study aimed to design and test brief interventions to help individuals make normatively better decisions. Specifically, we examined whether instructing participants to apply the Expected Value (EV) calculation strategy would enhance their performance in a financial decision task. Teaching EV calculations aligns with the concept of enhancing mindware (Stanovich et al., 2016), as it provides individuals with specialized cognitive tools that can improve their decision-making in lottery-based tasks. This approach also reflects the cognitive support framework in math anxiety interventions (Sammallahti et al., 2023). However, given that explicit calculations may be perceived as too complex or demanding, we also tested an alternative intervention: teaching simplified numerical estimation strategies (Siegler & Booth, 2005). By framing the task as an estimation problem rather than a strict mathematical computation, we aimed to make the decision process feel more intuitive and achievable, potentially reducing negative emotional responses and avoidance behaviors. This aligns with the emotion and motivation regulation approach in math anxiety intervention (Sammallahti et al., 2023).

Our main hypotheses were as follows: H1: Participants in both experimental groups (Calculation and Estimation conditions) will make more EV-consistent choices than the Control group. H2: Participants provided with estimation strategies (Estimation condition) will have more positive emotional reactions after the decision task than the participants encouraged to calculate EV (Calculation condition) as well as those given no additional instructions (Control condition).
Additionally, we explored the role of deliberation time and individual differences (e.g., numeracy, math anxiety) in predicting the number of EV-consistent choices.

div.head: Method Participants
div.p: Participants were recruited through the academic research system SONA and received credit points required for their degree. All participants were over 18 years old and were students at SWPS University. A total of 234 individuals took part in the study, with 214 providing eligible responses.

The study was preregistered (https://osf.io/ch6z8/?view_only=61c85bd2ef4c4546bbb417245fa3e11b) 1 , with a planned sample size of at least 189 participants, determined through a power analysis (1 -β = .95) to detect an effect size of f = .25 at α = .05. Responses were excluded if they were incomplete or showed no variance in answers. The final sample consisted of 154 women, 52 men, and 8 individuals who either preferred not to disclose their gender or identified as another gender. Most participants were from metropolitan areas (n = 108) and had a secondary education background (n = 123).

div.head: Materials
div.p: Lottery Task. We used 10 lottery problems developed by , adapted from Cokely & Kelley (2009). Each task presented participants with a choice between two options (e.g., Option A:

Lose PLN 50 for sure, or Option B: A 50% chance to lose PLN 400 and a 50% chance to lose nothing). The 10 tasks were randomized, and within each task, the presentation order of the options was also randomized. All participants received the same set of gambles. Each correct responsedefined as selecting the option with the higher expected value (EV)-was worth one point, allowing participants to achieve a maximum score of 10.

div.head: Emotional Response to Task Scale (ERTS).
div.p: To assess participants' emotional responses to the task, we used the Emotional Response to Task Scale (ERTS), which included five items-four measuring negative affect ("The study was difficult," "The study was unpleasant," "The study was boring," and "The study was stressful for me") and one measuring positive affect ("I liked the study"). Participants rated each statement on a 5-point scale, where 1 indicated "I don't agree" and 5 indicated "I agree."

Negative affect was calculated as the sum of responses to the four negative items, with higher scores indicating a stronger negative emotional response (Cronbach's α = .81). Positive affect was measured on a 1-5 scale, with higher scores reflecting a more positive response. Additionally, we created a composite ERTS score by summing the negative affect scores and reversing the positive affect score (Cronbach's α = .85), where higher values indicated a more negative overall reaction to the task. As with the lottery tasks, ERTS items were presented in a randomized order.

Subjective and Objective Numeracy. Numeracy was assessed using the 4-item Berlin Numeracy Test (BNT; Cokely et al., 2012) and the 8-item Subjective Numeracy Scale (SNS; Fagerlin et al., 2007). In the BNT, participants solved tasks that required an understanding of statistics and probability (e.g., "Imagine we are rolling a five-sided die 50 times. On average, how many times would the die land on an odd number?"). Scores ranged from 0 to 4, with higher scores indicating greater objective numeracy. In the SNS, participants rated their perceived numerical competence on a 6-point scale. Items assessed their confidence in working with numbers (e.g., "How good are you at working with percentages?") and their preference for numerical information (e.g., "How often do you find numerical information useful?").

Math Anxiety and Math Attitude. To assess individual differences in math anxiety and math attitudes, we used the Math Anxiety Questionnaire for Adults (MAQA) and the Mathematics Attitude Scale for Adults (MASA) (Szczygieł, 2021(Szczygieł, , 2023. These questionnaires have been tested with both student and non-student samples, demonstrating satisfactory reliability, making them ideal for this study. Notably, they were developed for the Polish population, which is the focus of our research. The MAQA was designed so that higher scores reflect greater math anxiety. This scale specifically avoids questions related to school-based math experiences (such as those involving teachers) and instead focuses on situations that may arise in everyday life, making it suitable for individuals outside of STEM fields. The MASA, on the other hand, measures individuals' attitudes toward mathematics across three dimensions: cognitive, affective, and behavioral. Higher scores on the MASA indicate a more positive attitude toward mathematics. Both the MAQA and MASA consist of 19 items each.

div.head: Procedure
div.p: Participants were randomly assigned to one of three experimental conditions using Qualtrics' built-in randomization functionality. The only difference between the conditions was the set of instructions provided before the Lottery tasks, as detailed in Table 1. In all conditions, participants first received the relevant instructions, followed by 10 lottery tasks, each requiring them to choose between two monetary gambles. After completing the decision tasks, participants rated their subjective experience using the Emotional Response to Task Scale. They then completed individual differences measures, including the BNT, SNS, MAQA, and MASA. Finally, demographic information, such as gender, current living location, and education level, was collected.

div.head: Main analyses
div.p: To test H1 and H2, we conducted one-way ANOVAs to examine whether the instructions influenced emotional reactions and consistency with EV-based choices. No statistically significant differences were found between conditions on any measure (see Table 2).

However, Lottery task scores showed a marginal effect, F(2, 211) = 2.40, p = .093, η² = 0.022. Given our preregistered H1, we conducted a planned contrast between the Calculation and Control conditions, revealing that participants in the Calculation condition made significantly more EV-consistent choices (M = 8.31, SD = 1.51) than those in the Control condition (M = 7.74, SD =

div.head: Exploratory analyses
div.p: In addition to the pre-registered analyses reported above, we conducted several exploratory analyses. Specifically, we examined the correlations between individual differences and lottery task scores, compared differences in deliberation time across conditions, and performed mediation analyses to explore potential mechanisms linking the experimental condition to the results obtained in the lottery task.

div.head: Individual differences and performance in a Lottery task
div.p: To examine whether numeracy, math anxiety and math attitudes are related to performance in the Lottery task and emotional experiences, we analyzed correlations between these variables (Table 3). Consistent with previous literature, the number of EV-consistent choices was significantly correlated with both objective numeracy (BNT; r = .23, p < .001) and subjective numeracy (SNS; r = .26, p < .001). Interestingly, we also found a similar relationship with math attitudes (MASA; r = .23, p < .001) and with math anxiety (r = -.15, p = .029).

Although the Emotional Response to Task Scale was not significantly correlated with performance in the Lottery Task, we observed relationships between emotional responses and individual difference measures. Specifically, higher objective numeracy, subjective numeracy, and more positive math attitudes were associated with experiencing weaker negative emotions while completing the Lottery Task (r = -.19, p = .005; r = -.26, p < .001; r = -.19, p = .005, respectively).
Conversely, higher math anxiety was linked to experiencing more negative emotions during the task (r = .36, p < .001). This pattern of results supports the validity of our measure.

div.head: Deliberation time
div.p: We also examined whether different instructions given to participants influenced deliberation time during decision-making. Deliberation time was calculated as the total time spent on all lotteries throughout the study. To test this, we conducted a one-way ANOVA, which revealed a statistically significant effect, F(2,211) = 8.476, p < .001, η² = 0.074. Participants in the Control group had the shortest deliberation time, while those in the Calculation condition took the longest, with the estimation condition falling in between (Table 4).

Since deliberation time did not follow a normal distribution (K-S = .190, p < .001), we also performed a Kruskal-Wallis test. Additionally, we applied a log transformation to the data to reduce the influence of outliers and approximate a normal distribution. Although the transformed data showed an improvement (K-S = .067, p = .020), it still deviated from normality. Nevertheless, both the original and transformed analyses produced consistent results.

Post hoc comparisons indicated a significant difference (p < .001) between the Control and Calculation conditions, while the difference between the Control and Estimation conditions was marginally significant (p < .10). Next, we investigated whether deliberation time was associated with making more EVconsistent choices and with higher scores on the individual differences questionnaires used in the study. To examine this, we analyzed correlations between deliberation time, lottery task performance, and questionnaire scores.

Importantly, we found that individuals who spent more time deliberating during the lottery task made more EV-consistent choices (r = .37, p < .001). Additionally, participants with higher objective numeracy (BNT) and subjective numeracy (SNS) tended to deliberate longer (r = .21, p = .003 and r = .17, p = .015, respectively). The correlation matrix is presented in Table 5.
In summary, deliberation time varied across experimental conditions and was also linked to individual differences in numeracy.

div.head: Mediation analysis
div.p: To investigate the mechanism central to our model, we conducted a mediation analysis using a bias-corrected bootstrapping procedure with 10,000 samples. Deliberation time (log-transformed) and the composite emotional reaction score (ERTS) were selected as potential mediators between the experimental condition and the outcome variable-the number of EV-consistent choices in the lottery task ( Figure 1).

Prior analyses indicated that the instruction to estimate, rather than simply calculate, did not offer advantages in terms of decision outcomes, emotional responses, or deliberation times. The mean performance in this group consistently fell between the control and calculation conditions. Therefore, we focused the mediation analysis on the two most extreme groups (Control = -0.5, Calculation = 0.5).

We found that the total effect of the intervention on lottery scores was statistically significant (B = 0.566, SE = 0.265, z = 2.136, p = .033, 95% CI = [0.035, 1.093]). However, the direct effect of the condition on lottery scores was not significant (B = 0.242, SE = 0.290, z = 0.833, p = .405, 95% CI = [-0.321, 0.819]).

We tested two potential indirect effects: one via deliberation time and the other via emotional reactions as mediators. The indirect effect of condition on lottery scores via emotional response was not significant (B = -0.065, SE = 0.054, z = -1.199, p = .231, 95% CI = [-0.232, 0.011]). In contrast, the indirect effect via deliberation time was significant (B = 0.388, SE = 0.130, z = 2.984, p = .003, 95% CI = [0.147, 0.715]).

These findings suggest that while emotional response did not significantly mediate the relationship between experimental condition and decision outcomes, deliberation time played a key role as a mediator between condition and lottery scores. Specifically, individuals who were instructed how to calculate expected values spent more time on the subsequent lottery task, which resulted in more EV-consistent choices. Note: * p < .05; ** p < .01; *** p < .001

div.head: Discussion
div.p: The present study explored the effects of different instructional interventions on financial decision-making, specifically focusing on the impact of Expected Value calculations and numerical estimation strategies on performance and emotional responses in a lottery task. We hypothesized that both calculation and estimation strategies would lead to more EV-consistent choices compared to the control group and that the estimation strategy would elicit more positive emotional reactions. While our findings did not fully support these hypotheses, we uncovered important insights into the role of deliberation time in financial decision-making.

Our study suggests that instruction on calculating Expected Values can enhance decisionmaking. Planned comparisons revealed that participants in the Calculation condition made significantly more EV-consistent choices than those in the Control group. Importantly, this effect was mediated by deliberation time, indicating that the intervention not only provided participants with specialized mindware (Stanovich et al., 2016) or a cognitive support tool (Sammallahti et al., 2023), but may have also influenced their numeric self-efficacy (Peters & Shoots-Reinhard, 2022) or motivation (Sammallahti et al., 2023), leading them to invest more effort in the task.

Nevertheless, we anticipated that this intervention (instruction on how to calculate Expected Values) could backfire if participants found the strategy too challenging, potentially evoking negative emotions. However, our mediation analysis showed that emotional reactions did not predict performance on the lottery task, suggesting that the benefits of the intervention outweighed the potential harm.

To mitigate the potential negative effects of the Calculation condition, we included an additional intervention in which participants not only received instructions on how to calculate the Expected Value but were also provided with estimation strategies aimed at reducing cognitive effort and negative emotions. However, we found no significant differences in emotional reactions between the Estimation and other conditions, suggesting that this manipulation was ineffective. We argue that designing interventions to address emotional reactions during numerical tasks (e.g., reducing state math anxiety) is inherently challenging, and the results of such studies are often mixed (Ganley et al., 2021;Sammallahti et al., 2023;Sidney et al., 2025). Future research is needed to refine and test strategies that effectively reduce emotional barriers to numerical tasks.

Finally, our study provides valuable insights for developing interventions that support decision-making. Specifically, future research should focus on providing individuals with cognitive strategies or tools that encourage greater effort in decision tasks. For example, in the case of the Cognitive Reflection Test, the most effective interventions leading to more reflective responses included extensive debiasing training, decision justification or monetary incentives (Isler & Yilmaz, 2022). Importantly, participants in our study were not incentivized for their choices. Future studies could investigate the impact of real or hypothetical financial incentives to determine whether such external motivators enhance the effectiveness of instructional interventions.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: In conclusion, this study provides valuable insights into the complex relationship between numeracy, motivation, and emotional reactions in financial decision-making. Our findings suggest that deliberation time plays a crucial role in making more EV-consistent choices. These results highlight the need for future research to develop more effective interventions that address both cognitive and motivational aspects of financial decision-making.

Additionally, the difference in the composite index for emotional reactions was not significant, F(2, 211) = 2.23, p = .110, η² = 0.021, with the highest mean in the Calculation condition (M = 13.13, SD = 4.89) and the lowest in the Control condition (M = 11.49, SD = 4.50
